metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Wife of Sheikh Abdul Khader

facts.text: The respondent is the wife of Sheikh Abdul Khader who resided abroad in Bangkok from September 1940 to July 1947.

During the period Sheikh Abdul Khader was abroad, he remitted monies in the name of his agent for payment to the respondent; aggregate amount in the account year relevant to assessment year 1942-43 was Rs. 9,180.
The respondent did not submit a return of her income as required.
The amount of Rs. 9,180 constituted income in the hands of the respondent under section 4(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.
Income-tax Officer issued notice under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 on July 25, 1949 upon receipt of definite information that income had escaped assessment.
Assessee was assessed on the income on October 24, 1949.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner; assessment confirmed.
Further appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras; unsuccessful.

Reference to High Court of Madras; question referred: Whether proceedings under section 34 initiated on 25th July 1949 to assess Rs. 9,180 escaped assessment for 1942-43 by failure to submit voluntary return are valid in law?

High Court answered the question in the negative, holding 8-year limitation under amended section 34 (1948 Act) not applicable as 4-year period expired before March 30, 1948; section 31 of 1953 Act not applicable.
Under pre-1948 section 34, limitation for notice and assessment expired March 31, 1947 (4 years from end of 1942-43).
Under post-1948 amended section 34, limitation extended to 8 years, till March 31, 1951.
Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 (XLVIII of 1948) passed September 8, 1948, section amending s.34 effective retrospectively from March 30, 1948.
Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 (XXV of 1953) passed May 24, 1953, effective retrospectively from April 1, 1952, contains section 31.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court on condition appellant pays costs in any event.

legal_issues.text: Whether the proceedings under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act initiated on 25th July, 1949, to assess the amount of Rs. 9,180 which escaped assessment during the year 1942-43 by failure to submit a voluntary return are valid in law?
Whether the amended section 34 (8-year limitation) by 1948 Act applies retrospectively to cases where 4-year limitation under old section had expired before March 30, 1948.
Whether section 31 of the Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 applies to validate the notice and assessment.

petitioner_arguments.text: The notice issued on July 25, 1949 was valid under amended section 34 providing 8-year limitation; 1948 amendment applies.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 34 as amended by Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948; Section 31 of Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 31 of 1953 Act declares that provisions of sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of section 34 shall apply and be deemed always to have applied to assessments for years ending before April 1, 1948 where proceedings commenced after September 8, 1948.

respondent_arguments.text: Initiation of proceedings on July 25, 1949 invalid as department's right governed by old section 34 with 4-year limitation expired March 31, 1947; 8-year period under 1948 amendment cannot be invoked retrospectively for failure to file return.
Section 31 of 1953 Act does not amend or purport to amend section 34; validity still governed by amended section 34 which does not apply retrospectively.

court_reasoning.text: K. Das J. agrees with facts stated by Kapur J. and reasons in S.C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas; High Court correctly answered the question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court contention well-founded; new 8-year limitation does not apply retrospectively.

court_reasoning.text: Kapur J.: Case governed by decision in S.C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court held 8-year limitation not applicable as 4-year period expired before amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J.: Section 31 of 1953 Act plainly applies sub-sections (1) and (3) of section 34 as amended in 1948 to proceedings commenced after September 8, 1948 for years ending before April 1, 1948; deems them always to have applied; validates notice and assessment if compliant with amended section.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notice issued July 25, 1949 and assessment October 24, 1949 satisfy conditions under amended s.34; legislature had power to give retrospective effect.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J.: Pre-1948 s.34 repealed; s.31 removes doubt by making amended s.34 applicable even if pre-existing limitation expired.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No justification to limit s.31 to cases where pre-existing time had not expired.

court_reasoning.text: Hidayatullah and Raghubar Dayal JJ. dealt with appeal in Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas.

holdings.text: In accordance with opinion of the majority, the appeal is allowed.
Notice under s.34 dated July 25, 1949 and assessment order dated October 24, 1949 are valid under s.34 as amended in 1948, by virtue of s.31 of 1953 Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Governs this case; judgment delivered same day; Das and Kapur JJ. agree with it; Hidayatullah and Raghubar Dayal JJ. judgment therein.
Mentioned that 1948 amendment by itself would not permit proceedings in 1949 for 1942-43.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs escaped assessment, limitation periods pre and post amendment; notice and assessment under s.34

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 (XLVIII of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended limitation to 8 years retrospectively from March 30, 1948; repealed old s.34

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 (XXV of 1953)
statutes_cited.relevance: Declares s.34 sub-ss.(1),(2),(3) as amended in 1948 deemed always to apply to proceedings commenced after Sept 8, 1948 for years before April 1, 1948; validates notices and assessments compliant therewith notwithstanding prior judgments.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the Commissioner's appeal in accordance with majority opinion, set aside High Court judgment, held notice under s.34 dated July 25, 1949 and assessment dated October 24, 1949 valid.
outcome.costs: Appellant to pay respondent's costs of appeal as per High Court certificate condition.

key_quotes.text: "For the removal of doubts it is hereby declared that the provisions of sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of section 34 of the principal Act shall apply and shall be deemed always to have applied to any assessment or reassessment for any year ending before the 1st day of April, 1948..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.31, 1953 Act central to majority holding on retrospectivity.

key_quotes.text: "Section 31 was enacted to remove that doubt and to make section 34 of the principal Act as it stood after the 1948 amendment applicable to these proceedings."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sarkar J.'s interpretation validating notice despite expired limitation.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion, the contention of the learned counsel for the assessee is well founded, that the new rule of limitation of eight years prescribed by the amended section 34 would not apply..."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's view overturned by Supreme Court.
